title: Start Your KDP Niche Research Like This - Low and Medium Content Books

tactics.name: Broad Search and Idea Gathering
tactics.description: Start with general categories on Amazon to collect niche ideas.
steps: Use best sellers list to identify broad categories
Scroll through results to note non-written book formats
caveats: Avoid niches with potential trademark issues
source_quotes: "We want to start really broad... look for those books that basically aren't written books."

tactics.name: narrow_search_terms
tactics.description: Iteratively refine search terms by adding specificity to identify high-potential niches
steps: Start with broad terms like 'activity book'
Add modifiers to narrow scope (e.g., 'maze book')
Analyze BSR and review data for refined terms
caveats: Trademark risks with certain niches like 'I Spy'
source_quotes: I avoid the I spy niche cause I think that has the potential for trademark issues

heuristics.name: Low-Content Format Focus
heuristics.condition: If books are non-written formats, prioritize them
source_quotes: "Logbooks are huge... they're relatively easy to create"

heuristics.name: review_volume_filter
heuristics.condition: If search term has high result volume but low review counts, prioritize
source_quotes: activity book had 70,000 results but maze book only 7,000

claims.statement: 80% of KDP sales occur in the US market
Targeted niche research outperforms random book creation for KDP success
source_quotes: you can be more targeted in your approach rather than...create random books

niche_patterns.description: Target low-content books with specific audience needs
niche_patterns.why_it_works: Evergreen demand with minimal creation effort
source_quotes: "Logbooks are... have this really strong evergreen market"

niche_patterns.description: Combine content type with demographic and thematic modifiers for specificity
niche_patterns.why_it_works: Balances broad appeal with niche differentiation
source_quotes: mazes for kids four to eight
